question: How are the cities of Rabat and Salee geographically related?
llm_answer: The cities of Rabat and Salee are geographically related in that they are both located on the Maroquine coasts of the Mediterranean and Atlantic waters, and Salee is 110 miles from Rabat.

Take this as a specimen,--   "Votre beaute, grande princesse,   Porte les traits dont elle blesse   Jusques aux plus sauvages lieux:   L'Afrique avec vous capitule,   Et les conquetes de vos yeux   Vont plus loin que celles d'Hercule." The Maroquine ambassador, who was also grand admiral of the Moorish navy, witnessing all the wonders of Paris at the epoch of the Great Monarch, was dazzled with its beauty and magnificence; nevertheless, he remained a good Mussulman. He was besides a grateful man, for he saw our James II. in exile, who had given the admiral liberty without ransom when he had been captured by English cruisers, and heartily thanked the fallen prince for his own freedom whilst he condoled with him in his misfortunes. But the Moorish envoy, in spite of his great influence, was unable to conclude the treaty of peace, which was desired by France. On his return to Morocco, the ambassador had so advanced in European ideas of convenience, or civilization, that he attempted to introduce a taste for Parisian luxury

it looks sufficiently fair and just, in the provision--"he (the English guilty subject) shall not be punished with more severity than a Moor could be," fairly made? In the first place, although this does not come under the idea of "serious personal injury," would the English people approve of their countrymen suffering the same punishment as the Moors for theft, by cutting off their right hand? Moors and Arabs have been so maimed for life, on being convicted of stealing property to the value of a single shilling! Who will take upon himself to enumerate the punishments, which may be, and are inflicted for grave offences? It may be replied that this stipulation of punishing British subjects, like Moorish, is only on paper, and we have no examples of its being put into execution. I rejoin, without attempting to cite proof, that, whilst such an article exists in a treaty, said to be binding on the Government of England as well as Morocco, there can be no real security for British subjects in this country; for in the event of the Maroquines acting strictly upon the articles of this treaty, what mode of inculpation, or what colour of right, can the British Government adopt or shew against them? and what are treaties made for, if they do not bind both parties? indeed by accident or miracle, justly decide upon the case of an Englishman, or upon a dispute between his own and a foreign subject; for besides the ideas and education of the Emperor, there is the necessity which his Imperial Highness feels, despot as he is, of exhibiting himself before his people as their undoubted friend and partial judge. So strongly have Sultans of Morocco felt this, that many anecdotes might be cited where the Emperor has indemnified the foreigner for injury done to him by his own subjects, whilst he has represented to them that he has decided the case against the stranger. It is surprising how a British Government could surrender the settlement of the dispute of their subjects to the final appeal of the Court of Morocco in the nineteenth century, and, moreover, allow them to be decided, according to the maxims of the Mohammedan code, or comformable to the Moorish law! It is not long ago since, indeed just before my arrival in Morocco, that the Emperor decided a dispute in rather a summary manner, without even the usual Moorish forms of judicial proceedure by decapitating, a quasi--European Jew, under French protection, and who once acted as the Consul of France. Morocco.--The tyraufc Yezeed, (half Irish).--Muley Suleiman, the "The Shereeff of Shereefs."--Diplomatic relations of the Emperor of Morocco with European Powers.--Muley Ismael enamoured with the French Princess de Conti.--Rival diplomacy of France and England near the Maroquine Court.--Mr. Hay's correspondence with this Court on the Slave-trade.--Treaties between Great Britain and Morocco; how defective and requiring amendment.--Unwritten engagements. CHAPTER III. The two different aspects by which the strength and resources of the Empire of Morocco may be viewed or estimated.--Native appellation of Morocco.--Geographical limits of this country.--Historical review of the inhabitants of North Africa, and the manner in which this region was successively peopled and conquered.--The distinct varieties of the human race, as found in Morocco.--Nature of the soil and climate of this country.--Derem, or the Atlas chain of mountains.--Natural products.--The Shebbel, or Barbary salmon; different characters of exports of the Northern and Southern provinces.--The Elaeonderron Argan.--Various trees and plants.--Mines.--The Sherb-Errech, or Desert-horse. CHAPTER IV. Division of Morocco into kingdoms or States, and zones or regions.-- Description of the towns and cities on the Maroquine coasts of the Mediterranean and Atlantic waters.--The Zafarine

In illustration of the way in which British subjects have their disputes sometimes settled, according to Articles VII and VIII, I take the liberty of introducing the case of Mr. Saferty, a respectable Gibraltar merchant, settled at Mogador. A few months before my arrival in that place, this gentleman was adjudged, in the presence of his Consul, Mr. Willshire, and the Governor of Mogador, for repelling an insult offered to him by a Moor, and sentenced to be imprisoned with felons and cut-throats in a horrible dungeon. However, Mr. Saferty was attended by a numerous body of his friends; so when the sentence was given, a cry of indignation arose, a scuffle ensued, and the prisoner was rescued from the Moorish police-officers. Mr. Willshire found the means of patching up the business with the Moorish authorities, and the case was soon forgotten. "All's well that ends well." I do not say that the Moors are determinedly vindictive, or seek quarrels with Europeans; on the contrary, I believe the cause of the dispute frequently rests with the European, and the bona-fide agressor, some adventurer whose conduct was so bad in his own country, that he sought Barbary as a refuge from the pursuit of the minister of justice. What I wish to lay stress on is, the enormous power given to the Emperor, by a solemn treaty, in making him the final judge,

of imports in 1855 was: British goods, L136,496 7_s_. 6_d_., foreign goods L31,222 11_s_. 5_d_. The trade last year was greatly increased by the unusually large demand for olive-oil from all parts, and there is no doubt that, under a more liberal Government, the commerce might be developed to a vast extent. RABAT. The principal goods imported at Rabat are, alum, calico of different qualities, cinnamon, fine cloth, army cloth, cloves, copperas, cotton prints, raw cotton, sewing cotton, cutlery, dimity, domestics, earthenware, ginger, glass, handkerchiefs (silk and cotton), hardware, indigo, iron, linen, madder root, muslin, sugar (refined and raw), tea, and tin plate. The before-mentioned articles are imported partly for consumption in Rabat and Sallee, and partly for transmission into the interior. The value of different articles of produce exported at Rabat during the last five years amounts to L34,860 1_s_. There can be no doubt that the imports and exports at Rabat would greatly increase, if the present high duties were reduced, and Government monopolies abolished. Large quantities of hides were exported before they were a Government monopoly: now the quantity exported is very inconsiderable. MAZAGAN. _Goods Imported_.--Brown

is a small town, but was formerly of considerable importance. A famous market for grain is held here, which is attended by the tribe of the Atlas: the country abounds in grain and cattle of the finest breed. Bulawan or Bou-el-Awan, "father of commodious ways or journeys," is a small town of 300 houses, with an old castle, formerly a place of consequence; and lying on an arm of the river Omm-Erbegh _en route_ from Morocco to Salee and Mequinez and commanding the passage of the river. It is 80 miles from Morocco, and 110 from Salee. On the opposite side of the river, is the village of Taboulaunt, peopled mostly with Jews and ferrymen. Soubeit is a very ancient city on the left bank of the Omm-Erbegh, surrounded with walls, and situate twenty miles from El-Medina in a mountainous region abounding with hares; it is inhabited by a tribe of the same name, or probably Sbeita, which is also the name of a tribe south of Tangier. Meramer is a city built by the Goths on a fertile plain, near Mount Beni-Megher, about fourteen miles east of Saffee, in the province of Dukkala, and carrying on a great commerce in oil and grain. El-Medina is a large walled populous city of merchants and

famous Sidi-el-Haj-el-Araby-Ben-Ali, who, in his district, lives in a state of nearly absolute independence, besides exercising great influence over public affairs. This saint, or priest, has, however, a rival at Tedda. The two popes together pretend to decide the fate of the Empire. The districts where these Grand Marabouts reside, are without governors, and the inhabitants pay no tribute into the imperial coffers, they are ruled by their two priests under a species of theocracy. The Emperor never attempts or dares to contest their privileges. Occasionally they appear abroad, exciting the people, and declaiming against the vices of the times. His Moorish Majesty then feels himself ill at ease, until they retire to their sanctuaries, and employs all his arts to effect the object, protesting that he will be wholly guided by their councils in the future administration of the Empire. With this humiliation of the Shereefs, they are satisfied, and kennel themselves into their sanctum-sanctorums. Zawiat-Muley-Driss, which means, retirement of our master, Lord Edris (Enoch) and sometimes called Muley Edris, is a far famed city of the province of Fez, and placed at the foot of the lofty mountains of Terhoun, about twenty-eight miles from Fez, north-west, amidst a most beautiful country, producing all the necessaries and luxuries of human

they must abide their decision (of unreason) and their excuses will not be accepted." This said article was confirmed as late as the year 1824 by the plenipotentiary of a nation, which boasts of being the most free and civilized of Europe, and whose people spend annually millions for the conversion of the heathen, and the extinction of the slave-trade. The last clause of Article IV also demands our attention, viz. "And if any English merchant should happen to have a vessel in or outside the port, he may go on board himself, or any of his people, without being liable to pay anything whatever." Now in spite of this (but of course forgotten) stipulation, the merchants of Mogador are not permitted to visit their own vessels, nor those of other persons which may happen to be in or outside the port. It is true, the authorities plead the reason of their refusal to be, "The merchants are indebted to the Emperor:" neither will the authorities take any security, and arbitrarily, and insolently prohibit, under any circumstances, the merchants from visiting their vessels. I have said enough to shew that our treaties (I beg the reader's pardon, "capitulations") with the Emperor of Morocco, require immediate revision, and to be amended with articles more suited to the spirit of the age, and European civilization, as likewise more consistent with the dignity of Great Britian. century--an epoch full of wars--during which, the Caliph Kaim transported the seat of his government from Kairwan to Cairo, ending in the complete submission of Morocco to the power of Yousef Ben Tashfin. One cannnot now distinguish which tribe of Arabs belong to the first or the second invasion, but all who can shew the slightest proof, claim to belong to the first, as ranking among a band of noble and triumphant warriors. After eight centuries of rule, the Arabs being expelled from Spain, took refuge in Barbary, but instead of finding the hospitality and protection of their brethren, the greater part of them were pillaged or massacred. The remnant of these wretched fugitives settled along the coast; and it is to their industry and intelligence that we owe the increase, or the foundation of many of the maritime cities. Here, considered as strangers and enemies by the natives, whom they detested, the new colonists sought for, and formed relations with Turks and renegades of all nations, whilst they kept themselves separate from the Arabs and Berbers. This, then, is the _bona-fide_ origin of the people whom we now generally call Moors. History furnishes us with a striking example of how the expelled Arabs of Spain united with various adventurers against the Berber and North African Arabs. communities.summary:
1. **Title**: Exploring North African Cities
2. **Summary**: The text chunks describe various cities in North Africa, including Salee, Fez, and Rabat, highlighting their historical significance, architectural features, and cultural practices. These cities have been influenced by different empires and civilizations, such as the Romans, Moors, and Spanish, leaving behind a rich legacy of trade, architecture, and traditions. The texts also mention the natural surroundings, including forests, rivers, and hills, which have shaped the development of these cities. The region is home to a diverse population, including Muslims, Jews, and Christians, with a strong presence of Moorish saints and Sufi traditions.
3. **Keywords**: North Africa, Moorish Cities, Historical Trade, Islamic Architecture, Cultural Heritage

1. **Title**: Moroccan Cities and Geography
2. **Summary**: The text describes various cities and regions in Morocco, including their geography, history, and cultural significance. Cities such as Tetouan, Ceuta, Fez, and Rabat are mentioned, along with their architectural features, trade, and cultural practices. The text also touches on the country's history, including the influence of the Portuguese, Arabs, and Berbers. The regions of Morocco are described in terms of their natural resources, climate, and agricultural production. The text provides a comprehensive overview of Morocco's urban and rural landscapes, highlighting the country's rich cultural heritage and geographic diversity.
3. **Keywords**: Morocco, Cities, Geography, History, Culture

1. **Title**: Moroccan Trade and Geography
2. **Summary**: The text chunks discuss various aspects of Morocco, including its trade, geography, and culture. The country's ports, such as Mogador, Tangier, and Rabat, are major hubs for the export of goods like almonds, wool, and olive oil, and the import of goods like cotton, sugar, and tea. The chunks also describe the country's cities, like Fez, Taza, and Zawiat-Muley-Driss, and their historical and cultural significance. Additionally, the text mentions the influence of Grand Marabouts, or religious leaders, in the country's governance and the role of the Shereefs, or descendants of the Prophet Muhammad, in Moroccan society.
3. **Keywords**: Morocco, Trade, Geography, Marabouts, Shereefs

1. **Title**: Morocco and its Empire
2. **Summary**: The text chunks discuss the history, geography, and culture of Morocco, including its rulers, such as Muley Abd Errahman and Muley Suleiman, and their impact on the empire. The chunks also touch on the country's relations with European powers, the treatment of slaves and women, and the daily life of Jews and Moors in Morocco. The empire's geography, climate, and natural resources are also described, highlighting the country's strategic location and diverse population. The text also explores the complexities of Moroccan society, including the role of the Shereefs and the influence of Islam.
3. **Keywords**: Morocco, Empire, Muley Abd Errahman, Shereefs, Islam

1. **Title**: Morocco and its Royal Cities
2. **Summary**: The text describes the state of Morocco and its royal cities, including Fez, Mequinez, and Tafilett, which are in decline. The country is ruled by the Shereefs, a dynasty of African blood, and the Sultan's presence is necessary to maintain allegiance in the north. The cities are characterized by their unique cultural and architectural features, such as the use of Dutch tiles and the production of wool and silk manufactures. The text also mentions the bombardment of Mogador by the French and the subsequent pillage and violence perpetrated by wild tribes. The British Consul and his wife narrowly escaped with their lives, and the city was left in a state of destruction.
3. **Keywords**: Morocco, Fez, Mequinez, Tafilett, Shereefs, Mogador

1. **Title**: Maya Civilization Connections
2. **Summary**: The text discusses the potential connections between the Maya civilization and other ancient cultures, including the Egyptians, Chaldeans, and Etruscans. The author highlights similarities in language, writing systems, and symbolism between these cultures, suggesting that there may have been communication and exchange between them in the distant past. The author also describes their own research and discoveries, including the deciphering of Maya inscriptions and the identification of identical characters and symbols in different cultures. The text also touches on the idea that the Maya civilization may have had roots in Atlantis, and that their language and customs show similarities with those of other ancient cultures.
3. **Keywords**: Maya Civilization, Ancient Cultures, Linguistic Connections, Symbolism, Archaeology

1. **Title**: Natural History and Human Nutrition
2. **Summary**: The provided text chunks discuss various topics related to natural history, including the discovery of a new bird species, the Ocellated Pheasant, and its characteristics. Additionally, the chunks touch on human nutrition, exploring the idea that humans are naturally frugivorous and discussing the adaptability of the human digestive system to different food sources. The texts also mention the importance of understanding the utilization of food for bodily functions and the classification of substances as food or non-food. The discussion on bird species and human nutrition seems to be the main theme, with some chunks providing detailed descriptions of the Ocellated Pheasant's physical characteristics and others delving into the history of human dietary habits.
3. **Keywords**: Ocellated Pheasant, Human Nutrition, Natural History, Bird Species, Frugivorous Diet

1. **Forest Creatures Gather**: 
2. **Summary**: The text chunks describe a series of events involving various forest creatures, including a bear, a hawk, a wood-pigeon, and a boy. The hawk, initially portrayed as a threat, is shown to be starving and desperate, leading to a discussion about the morality of eating other creatures. 1. **North African Ethnicities**
2. The text discusses the various ethnic groups present in North Africa, including Berbers, Arabs, Moors, Jews, and others. The distinction between these groups is often blurred, particularly in urban areas where they have intermixed. The population of North Africa is characterized by a high degree of homogeneity in terms of religion, with the majority of people practicing Islam. The text also touches on the history of the region, including the expulsion of Arabs from Spain and their subsequent migration to North Africa. The various cities and towns in the region, such as Tunis, Tripoli, and Marrakech, are also described, highlighting their unique cultural and demographic characteristics. Overall, the text provides a comprehensive overview of the complex ethnic and cultural landscape of North Africa.
3. **Keywords**: North Africa, Ethnicities, Berbers, Arabs, Moors

1. **Mystery of the Fugitive**
2. The story revolves around a young boy named Gallegher, who becomes entangled in a mystery involving a suspected fugitive, Hade, and a detective, Hefflefinger. Gallegher's knowledge of the city's underworld and his keen observations lead him to suspect a man with a prosthetic finger, who may be connected to the Burrbank murder. As the story unfolds, Gallegher works with the detective and a sporting editor to uncover the truth and potentially capture the fugitive. The plot thickens as they devise a plan to apprehend the suspect at a high-stakes fight, with Gallegher's sharp instincts and the detective's expertise playing crucial roles. The narrative explores themes of suspense, intrigue, and the complexities of human nature.
3. **Keywords**: Mystery, Fugitive, Detective, Burrbank Murder, Suspense

1. **Title**: Ancient Musical Instruments

The text also highlights the similarities and differences between instruments from different cultures and regions. The ancient civilizations of Mexico, Greece, and Rome are noted for their advanced musical instruments and practices. The use of instruments in different contexts, such as warfare and religious ceremonies, is also explored.
3. **Keywords**: Ancient Instruments, Musical History, Cultural Exchange

1. **Title**: Lost in the Wilderness
2. **Summary**: The story revolves around the experiences of a young prospector, Jack Fleming, who becomes lost in the woods while searching for gold. He encounters a young girl at a cabin and attempts to borrow a pan to test the soil for gold. Meanwhile, another character, Mr. Edward Brice, is reuniting with a woman named Flora Dimwood, and they discuss their past and future plans. The narrative also touches on the theme of pursuit, as a character named Masterton chases a messenger through the snowy terrain. The story explores the challenges of navigating the wilderness, the importance of human connections, and the pursuit of goals.
3. **Keywords**: Wilderness, Prospecting, Gold, Pursuit, Reunion

1. **Title**: Exploring Cornwall's Landscapes
2. **Summary**: The text chunks describe the author's experiences and observations while traveling through Cornwall, a region in England. The author recounts their encounters with the local landscape, including the Lizard Peninsula, Land's End, and the Logan Rock. They also interact with the local people, visit shops, and experience the region's unique weather patterns, including a intense storm. The author reflects on the importance of mindset in traveling and the value of simplicity in exploration. The text also touches on the region's history, folklore, and natural beauty, showcasing the author's appreciation for the area's distinctive character.
3. **Keywords**: Cornwall, Travel, Landscape, Nature, Exploration
